text: - [Instructor] Hi.

We'll be looking at Amazon
CloudWatch Database Insights
in this video.
To explore Database Insights,
let us navigate to Amazon CloudWatch.
Under Insights on the left hand side,
we have Database Insights.
In the database insights,
there are two dashboards that we see.
The first is the Fleet Health Dashboard,

and the second one is
Database Instance Dashboard.
Let us explore each of these one by one.

The Fleet Health Dashboard
provides a snapshot view
of the health of your database fleet.
A database fleet is a group of databases
that you wanna monitor.

A monitoring view for a
database fleet can be created
on save as a fleet by choosing filters
like Instance, Cluster, Engine,
Endpoint, VPCID, or Tags.
The saved database fleet can be used
for purposes like frequent access
or for grouping database instances.
Once you have a database fleet selected,

the instance state summary
on the right hand side

presents a honeycomb
representing the nodes
within that fleet.

To get to know more
information about an instance,
you can choose a honeycomb,

to view the summary of the
corresponding instance.

Each honeycomb is
displayed in relevant color

to highlight the database
instance, current utilization,
such as High, Warning, Okay, or Idle.
The chart on the right hand side
provides the top 10 database instances
per DB load utilization.

That is the ratio of the
database load to the number
of virtual CPUs in terms of percentage.
The events chart provides a summary
of all the events from the database fleet
grouped by their severity.

You can also select the
details within the chart
to get to know more about the summary
of these highlighted events.

The details of events can
be filtered using options

like Severity, Category,
Event Name, or Instance.
The calling services chart provides a list
of CloudWatch application signal services

that are calling the database
endpoints of this fleet.
The two top 10 instances per metric charts
that here are on the left hand side
and the right hand side,

help you quickly identify
the top database instances
in terms of their utilization
based on the following metrics,

CP Utilization, Free Able
Memory, DB Connections,
Cetwork Throughput, Read IOPS, Write IOPS,
Read Latency, and Write Latency.

The RDS instances overview
table at the bottom
of the dashboard provides a list

of all the database
instances in this plate

and a direct link, which
navigates to the database

instance dashboard to explore
more details of this instance.

Now let us explore database
instance dashboard.
There are a few ways we could navigate
to the instance dashboard.
One is by selecting the honeycomb
and the Fleet Health instance summary.
Another way is to navigate by going

to the RDS instances
overview table at the bottom,

and selecting the required
database instance.

The database instance dashboard
provides a snapshot view
of the health of a database instance.

For the database instance
that is selected,
the database load chart provides graphs
for key metrics like Database, Host,

SQL, User, Weights,
Application, and Session Type.

Currently, the application
and session type

are only supported for
Aurora Postgres SQL.
These metrics are collected every second

to display the activities
in your database instances.
The explore button on the right hand side

opens up a topology map
of the related services
of the selected database instance.
This provides better visibility
for easier operational troubleshooting.

Selecting each of these
icon within the topology map

pulls the related metrics
and logs for that service.
For the selected database instance,
the DB load analysis tab

provides the top
contributors to the DB load
for the same dimensions mentioned earlier,

that is Database, Host,
SQL, User, Weights,
Application and Session Type.

We have a top dimension
sorted in a quick view.

The database telemetry tab
provides charts for metrics

and logs for the selected
database instance.

The metrics displayed in
the dashboard are customized
for the relevant database engine type.

The logs tab provides a
view of the database logs
exported to CloudWatch logs
for the selected database instance.

Slow SQL Queries tab displays
reports for database,

which have log exports
enabled to CloudWatch logs

and configured with database
parameters for SQL queries
and query patterns.
Slow SQL Query selection provides a list

of slow query patterns
sorted by their frequency.

The events tab provides
a table of RDS events
for the selected database instance.

The OS processes chart
provides a list of processes
that are running on the database instance

at a specific timestamp with
the details of the consumption
of resources on that instance.
For Performance Analysis tab,

lists on demand performance
analysis reports
for your database instance in your fleet,

which can be done anytime
using the analyst performance
button on the top right corner
within the database load chart.
Once the report analysis is generated,

it's listed under performance
analysis reports tab,
select the desired report from the list,
which opens up a new tab,

and displays a detailed report
of the database instance.
Lastly, the calling services chart

provides a list of CloudWatch
application signal,
both the services and operations
that are calling the database instance.
